items.item_details:
Background and Analysis:
	 
On August 25, 2014, the Registrar of Voters of the County of Santa Clara certified that Pearl Cheng and Bruce Swenson were the only two persons to file a Declaration for Candidacy for the district's two governing board member positions in the November 4, 2014, election and that no petition requesting that the election be held was received within the time frame provided by law. Pursuant to Education Code Section 5328, Pearl Cheng shall be seated at the organizational meeting for a new four-year term as governing board member and serve exactly as if elected at a general district election for such office.
	 
Chancellor Linda Thor will administer the oath of office to Pearl Cheng.
	 
Submitted by:
Chancellor Linda Thor
Additional contact names:
					 
Is backup provided?
Yes

items.item_details:
Background and Analysis:
	 
Revised board policy 3100 (formerly 2220) regarding the district's organizational structure was presented for first reading at the November 3, 2014, meeting. The revisions update language, remove processes covered by collective bargaining agreements, and change the title and policy number to align with the Community College League of California's Policy and Procedure templates.
	 
The revised policy was approved by the Chancellor's Advisory Council on October 24, 2014. 
	 
References:
Education Code Section 72400
	 
Submitted by:
Linda Thor, Chancellor
Additional contact names:

Yes

Proposed changes to grants board policy 3280 (formerly 3124) were considered at the Board of Trustees meeting of November 3, 2014, and the policy was revised further based on trustee input received at the meeting. The policy has been amended to update terminology, move grant guidelines to a newly created administrative procedure, and change the policy number and title to correspond with the system used by the Community College League of California's Policy and Procedure Service. 
	 
The revised policy was approved by the Chancellor's Advisory Council on October 24, 2014.

items.item_details:
Background and Analysis:
	 
The proposed retirement of the district's indirect costs board policy (BP 3160) was presented at the November 3, 2014, Board of Trustees meeting.  The policy has not been reviewed in many years and is not among those recommended by the Community College League of California as legally required, legally advised, or good practice. The second paragraph of the policy regarding assessment of grants that do not provide for indirect costs has been incorporated into the new grants administrative procedure (AP 3280).
	 
The Chancellor's Advisory Council approved the policy retirement on October 24, 2014.
	 
Submitted by:
Linda Thor, Chancellor
Additional contact names:
					 
Is backup provided?
Yes

The policy was approved by the Chancellor's Advisory Council on October 24, 2014.

items.item_details:
Background and Analysis:
	 
Senate Bill 860 (2014) added Education Code Section 78220, which states:
“As a condition for receiving Student Success and Support Program funding, and in order to ensure equal educational opportunities and to promote student success for all students, regardless of race, gender, age, disability, or economic circumstances, the governing board of each community college district shall maintain a student equity plan …”
The intent of the student equity planning process is for colleges to conduct a self-evaluation aimed at improving successful outcomes for all students.
The De Anza  College Equity Action Council, a shared governance committee with broad college representation, began working on the equity plan in winter of 2014.  The workgroup reviewed data and evidence disaggregated by various subpopulations to identify where outcomes indicated that some groups were disproportionately impacted compared to others.  They then identified indicators and goals as well as plans for activities aimed at reducing differences in outcomes.
The De Anza College Student Equity Plan was approved by the Planning and Budget teams and Campus Budget in Fall 2014.  It will be used to guide the use of the Equity funding to be received by the college.
	 
Submitted by:
 De Anza College President Brian Murphy ext. 8705
Additional contact names:
 De Anza College AVP Instruction Rowena Tomaneng ext. 8510
Is backup provided?
 Yes
items.item_recommendation: De Anza College President Brian Murphy recommends approval.
items.item_text: De Anza College Student Equity Plan
items.item_text_raw: 8. De Anza College Student Equity Plan

items.item_details:
Background and Analysis:
	 
Senate Bill 860 (2014) added Education Code Section 78220, which states:
	 
“As a condition for receiving Student Success and Support Program funding, and in order to ensure equal educational opportunities and to promote student success for all students, regardless of race, gender, age, disability, or economic circumstances, the governing board of each community college district shall maintain a student equity plan …”
	 
The intent of the student equity planning process is for colleges to conduct a self-evaluation aimed at improving successful outcomes for all students.
	 
The Foothill College Student Equity Workgroup, a shared governance committee with broad college representation, began working on the equity plan in winter of 2014.  The workgroup reviewed data and evidence disaggregated by various subpopulations to identify where outcomes indicated that some groups were disproportionately impacted compared to others.  They then identified indicators and goals as well as plans for activities aimed at reducing differences in outcomes. 
	 
The Foothill College Student Equity Plan was approved by the Planning and Resource Council (PaRC) on October 1, 2014.  It will be used to guide the use of the Equity funding to be received by the college.
	 
Submitted by:
Judy C. Miner, Foothill College President
Additional contact names:
Kimberlee Messina, Andrew LaManque
Is backup provided?
Yes
items.item_recommendation: The Foothill College Administration recommends approval of the Foothill College Student Equity Plan.

items.item_details:
Background and Analysis:
	 
Foothill seeks board approval for application to the State Chancellor's Office for the certificate of achievement.  This certificate meets the requirements established by the State Chancellor’s Office.
	 
The Personal Trainer Certificate of Achievement program is a multi-disciplinary educational experience. Instruction emphasizes assessment, program development and proper mechanics through the principles of anatomy and exercise physiology, psychology and small business practices and how to start and run a small business. Hands-on experience is available to the student intern through an array of fitness industry professional internships. Through the program, students will intern with small businesses and or corporate gyms, working with potential employers. Students interested in being self employed or owning their own businesses in the health and fitness industry, personal training, group exercise, nutrition, or other allied health fields are candidates for this program. Graduates will gain the knowledge needed to prepare them to take industry standard national certifications such as NASM (National Academy of Sports Medicine), ACE(American Council on Exercise), and ACSM (American College of Sports Medicine).
	 
The new certificate has been approved by Foothill's curriculum committee.
	 
Submitted by:
Judy C. Miner, Foothill College President
Additional contact names:
Kimberlee Messina, Andrew LaManque, Isaac Escoto
Is backup provided?
Yes
items.item_recommendation: The Foothill Administration recommends approval of the Certificate of Achievement, Personal Trainer.
items.item_text: Foothill College - Approval of the Certificate of Achievement, Personal Trainer
items.item_text_raw: 11. Foothill College - Approval of the Certificate of Achievement, Personal Trainer

items.item_details:
Background and Analysis:
	 
Education Code 84040(b) requires that each governing board of each community college district provide an annual audit of all funds, books, and accounts of the district in accordance with regulations of the Board of Governors.  Vavrinek, Trine, Day & Company, LLP, Certified Public Accountants, located in Pleasanton, California, completed the Foothill-De Anza Community College District annual audit for the year ended June 30, 2014, and the District Audit and Finance Committee will have reviewed the audit report on December 4, 2014, prior to the Board meeting.
	 
The external auditorâs report issued a clean, unqualified, opinion for all audited records, financial and compliance.  There were not audit findings noted in the audit report.
	 
The Board is requested to accept the audit report.  A copy of the report is available for public viewing in the Chancellorâs Office.
	 
Submitted by:
 Kevin McElroy, Vice Chancellor, Business Services, x6201
Additional contact names:
 Hector Quinonez, Executive Director, Fiscal Services, x6250
Is backup provided?
 Yes

items.item_details:
Background and Analysis:
	 
On June 6, 2006, voters in the Foothill-De Anza Community College District approved a $490.8 million general obligation bond measure (Measure C) under the rules established by Proposition 39.  Proposition 39 accountability requirements include annual performance and financial audits on use of bond proceeds. 
	 
The Measure C performance and financial audits were prepared by the independent certified public accounting firm of Vavrikek, Trine, Day & Company, LLP, located in Pleasanton, California.  The performance audit was prepared in accordance with Education Code Section 15286, which requires that the audit be conducted in accordance with Governmental Auditing Standards, issued by the Comptroller General of the United States. 
	 
The financial audit was conducted in accordance with auditing standards generally accepted in the United States and the standards applicable to financial audits contained in Governmental Auditing Standards, issued by the Comptroller General of the United States.
	 
The District Audit and Finance Committee will have reviewed the Measure C Performance and Financial Audit reports at their regularly scheduled meeting on December 4, 2014.  Copies of the reports are available for public viewing in the Chancellor's Office.
	 
Submitted by:
 Kevin McElroy, Vice Chancellor, Business Services, x6201
Additional contact names:
 Hector Quinonez, Executive Director, Fiscal Services, x6250
Is backup provided?
 Yes
items.item_recommendation: Vice Chancellor, Business Services Kevin McElroy recommends that the Board accept the Measure C performance and financial audit reports for the year ended June 30, 2014.

items.item_details:
Background and Analysis:
	 
Provisions with SB 564 require local agencies to report all external investments on a quarterly basis.  In accordance with the aforementioned requirement, attached is a listing of the District’s investments as of September 30, 2014.
	 
The District’s cash, in the amount of $217,242,077.56, is invested in the County’s Commingled Investments Pool.  As of on September 30, 2014, the current yield on the commingled investments pool was 0.48%.  As a comparison to the same time period, the yield on a two-year Treasury Note was 0.57%; the yield on a 6-month Treasury Bill was 0.03%; and the State of California Local Agency Investment Fund (LAIF) yield was 0.25%.
	 
Submitted by:
 Kevin McElroy, Vice Chancellor, Business Services, x6201

items.item_details:
Background and Analysis:
	 
The District installed four (4) Capstone C60 60 kW microturbines at the Foothill campus and four (4) Capstone C60 60 kW microturbines at the De Anza campus in 2005 as part of its energy savings program. The microturbines produce energy to heat the swimming pools and provide electricity to the campuses.
	 
To ensure proper turbine performance and life, the units require regular, proper maintenance according to the manufacturer's recommended practices. Capstone has a prescribed set of scheduled maintenance items that must be followed.  The maintenance agreement with Capstone Turbine Corporation expired on June 30, 2014.
	 
In 2010, Capstone elevated its California partner, Regatta Solutions (Regatta), from a sales representative to a full distributor that sells, installs, and services all Capstone microturbine energy products.  Capstone has since subcontracted the maintenance of the Districts’ eight microturbines to Regatta.  Currently Regatta is the exclusive Capstone approved distributer for California, Oregon, Washington, and Hawaii (see attached).
	 
Since Regatta is the manufacturer’s only distributor that can provide maintenance service on the microturbines in California there is no public benefit in conducting an advertised competitive sealed bid process; Regatta Solutions would be the only qualified bidder.  The five (5) year maintenance price from Regatta for all eight (8) microturbines in accordance with Capstone’s Standard Maintenance Schedule is $384,286.20 ($192,143.10 per campus over five years).  The plan includes scheduled and unscheduled maintenance, parts and labor, software updates and engine overhauls at 40,000 hours run time. Regatta’s proposal has been reviewed by Purchasing staff and Plant Services staff; compared to previous Capstone contracts staff believe that the rates for the proposed services are fair and reasonable.
	 
The expense for this maintenance is offset by the utility savings from the microturbines and is paid for out of the District utility budget.
	 
Submitted by:
  Pam Grey, Ext 6166
Additional contact names:
  Steve Kitchen, Ext 6150 Lester Lyons, Ext 6153, Gina Bailey, Ext. 6165
Is backup provided?
  No
items.item_recommendation: Director of Purchasing Services Pam Grey recommends that the Board of Trustees authorize the award of two maintenance service contracts to Regatta Solutions in an aggregate amount not to exceed $384,286.20 for a 5-year term.
items.item_text: Authorize two contracts between the District and Regatta Solutions for maintenance service of eight (8) 60kW Capstone C60 microturbines (ACTION)

items.item_details:
Background and Analysis:
	 
On January 7, 2013, the Board of Trustees authorized an 18-month lease for a 12’ x 40’ modular restroom during the renovation of the District Office Building (DOB). The lease expires December 5, 2014; however, the restroom facility continues to be required until the New District Office building is completed.  Therefore, District staff reached out to Mobile Modular to negotiate a contract extension or purchase the restroom outright. Staff anticipates that the need for the restroom will extend through June 30, 2018. If the District were to purchase the restroom, the purchase price would be $63,218.00.  The 44-month lease extension is $47,352.00, including the return costs.  Measure C will fund the project.
	 
Pursuant to Education Code 81526 “(a) The governing board of a community college district may lease relocatable structures for a term extending to the expected duration of use by the district, but not to exceed 10 years.  (b) Any lease agreement or contract entered into pursuant to this section shall be initiated by resolution authorizing such action and prescribing the terms thereof adopted by vote of a majority of the members of the governing board.”
	 
Submitted by:
  Pam Grey, Ext. 6166
Additional contact names:
  Steve Kitchen, Ext. 6150, Art Heinrich, Ext. 6295
Is backup provided?
  Yes
items.item_recommendation: Approve the extension of the lease agreement between the District and Mobile Modular Inc. for an additional 44 months, through June 30, 2018 at a total cost of $47,352 plus applicable taxes and adopt the attached Resolution #2014-39 entitled âResolution of the Governing Board of Foothill De Anza Community College District to Extend the Lease of a Relocatable Structure.â
items.item_text: Approve the extension of a Lease Agreement with Mobile Modular Inc. - $47,352
items.item_text_raw: A) Approve the extension of a Lease Agreement with Mobile Modular Inc. - $47,352

items.item_details:
Background and Analysis:
	 
On January 7, 2013, the Board of Trustees authorized an 18-month lease for a 48’ x 40’ modular structure during the renovation of Building 5800 to house the Disability Resource Center. Although the Building 5800 renovation is now complete, the District continues to require the space for its relocated staff during planning and construction of the New District Offices project.
Therefore, District staff reached out to Mobile Modular to negotiate a contract extension or purchase the modular office outright. Staff anticipates that the need for the modular office will extend through June 30, 2018. If the District were to purchase the restroom, the purchase price would be $75,841.00.  The 41-month lease extension is $68,013.00, including the return costs.  Measure C will fund the project.
	 
Pursuant to Education Code 81526 “(a) The governing board of a community college district may lease relocatable structures for a term extending to the expected duration of use by the district, but not to exceed 10 years.  (b) Any lease agreement or contract entered into pursuant to this section shall be initiated by resolution authorizing such action and prescribing the terms thereof adopted by vote of a majority of the members of the governing board.”
	 
Submitted by:
  Pam Grey, Ext. 6166
Additional contact names:
  Steve Kitchen, Ext. 6150, Art Heinrich, Ext. 6295
Is backup provided?
  Yes
items.item_recommendation: Approve the extension of the lease agreement between the District and Mobile Modular Inc. for an additional 41 months, through June 30, 2014 at a total cost of $68,013.00 plus applicable taxes and adopt the attached Resolution #2014-40 entitled â Resolution of the Governing Board of Foothill De Anza Community College District to Extend the Lease of a Relocatable Structure.â
items.item_text: Approve the extension of a Lease Agreement with Mobile Modular Inc. - $68,013

A credit is also realized for the District’s portion of the unused balance of the contractor’s contingency fund, 25% of which was paid to the contractor as a savings incentive in accordance with the provisions of the Facilities Lease. 
	 
This change plus all previously approved change orders equal to -3.3% of the base contract value.   These credits will be used to increase funding to the next stages of site and building construction.

items.item_details:
Background and Analysis:
	 
Title: Change #3
Vendor:  C.W. Driver
Agreement Date:  September 10, 2012
Campus:  FHDA Education Center
Project Number:  801
Project Name:  Foothill-DeAnza Education Center
Amount:  $59,342.00
For:
	 
Additional preconstruction services due to delays in the project and increases in scope of services.  
	 
C. W, Driver’s (CWD) original fees were based upon the schedule and scope of services included in the original Request for Proposals issued by the District.  The project schedule was lengthened, primarily due to delays in property turnover by the Air Force at the beginning of the project, requiring additional staff time by CWD.  
	 
In order to ensure timely overall completion of the project, the District has requested additional bidding phase services to allow site work and street improvements to be bid concurrently with Division of the State Architect reviews.  
	 
The additional fees are within the project budget.
	 
Submitted by:
Steve Kitchen, Executive Director, Facilities and Operations, extension 6150
Additional contact names:
Art Heinrich, Director, Bond Program Management, Foothill College
Is backup provided?
Yes
items.item_recommendation: Approval

items.item_details:
Background and Analysis:
	 
This project will bring Smithwick Theater hardware up to district standards and provide security improvements to the building. The scope of work includes door hardware replacement and select door replacement for existing theater while building remains fully occupied.  Improvement will be made on lower, main, and mezzanine levels and consist of new locks, cylinders, cores, and miscellaneous hardware.  Alternates #1 and #2 includes providing and installing new fiber reinforced polyester (FRP) doors and hardware. Project is anticipated to start construction in the middle of March 2015 and complete construction in early April 2015. 
	 
Prodis Associates Architects prepared the construction documents and a complete set of all bid documents are on file in the Purchasing Services Department. 
	 
Bid #1707-120 was legally advertised to contractors October 2, 2014, and October 8, 2014.  The “Invitation to Bid” was also sent to nine (9) builders’ exchanges, advertised in the San Jose Post Record, and posted on “BidNet” at www.govbids.com.  A mandatory bid walk was held on Oct. 22, 2014, and a total of seven (7) contractors attended the walk.  Bids were publicly opened and read on November 5, 2014 in the Purchasing Services office.  Five (5) contractors submitted a bid and the bid results are summarized below:
	 
General Contractors
Base Bid Proposal Amount Includes $10,000 Allowance 1
Alternate 1
Alternate 2
Total Base Bid Proposal Amount Plus Alternates 1 & 2 
Rodan Builders, Inc.
$96,000
$6,600
$7,800
$110,400
ER Brothers Company, Inc.
$99,440
$11,600
$12,700
$123,740
R.C. Benson & Sons, Inc. General Contractors
$106,860
$8,300
$8,300
$123,460
Swenson & Associates
$136,000
$10,500
$10,500
$157,000
Integra Construction Services Inc. 
$139,512
$4,450
$4,450
$147,900
	 
Rodan Builders, Inc. and its listed subcontractor have each signed the “Agreement To Be Bound” and the “Agreement of Contractors” of the Project Stabilization/Construction Careers Agreement between the District and the Santa Clara & San Benito Counties Building and Construction Trades Council.  
Purchasing Services staff have confirmed that Rodan Builders, Inc. has successfully completed projects for Silicon Valley Clean Water, San Francisco State University, and San Mateo Union High School District.  In addition, they have substantially completed Project 100O, Tennis Courts Renovation at Foothill College. 
The base bid proposal price of $96,000 (base bid + allowance $10,000) submitted by Rodan Builders, Inc. is over the construction estimate of $90,000, however, that amount did not include the $10,000 allowance. 
	 
Therefore, the Measure C Bond team recommends award of a contract for the base bid proposal amount plus Alternates 1 and 2 to Rodan Builders, Inc.  This project is funded by Measure C.
	 
Submitted by:
Pam Grey, Director of Purchasing Services
Additional contact names:
Art Heinrich, Steve Kitchen, Annette Perez
Is backup provided?
No
items.item_recommendation: Authorize the Director of Purchasing Services, Pam Grey, to award a contract pursuant to Bid Document #1707-120, Smithwick Theater Hardware Improvements in the amount of $110,400 to Rodan Builders, Inc.
